p: Diseases of the CNS (depression, Parkinson, Alzheimer, etc.) are incurable chronic conditions, and presumably that is why there has been an increasing number of studies in R. officinalis over recent years, in an attempt to find new solutions. Regarding depression there are several studies reporting a decreasing immobility time and regulation of several neurotransmitters (dopamine, norepinephrine, serotonin and acetylcholine) and gene expression in mice brain like TH, PC and MAPK phosphatase (MKP-1) [ 115, 116]. These studies contribute to the understanding of molecular mechanism behind the antidepressant effect of R. officinalis and its major active compounds.
